entertainment venues such as nightclubs and theatres will be ldquosubject to further public health advice.

title: everyone-get-500-shopping-voucher-uk-government-scheme
story: EVERYONE in the UK could be given a pound shopping voucher under new proposals to help kickstart the economy after the coronavirus lockdown.Itrsquos thought the plans could encourage the public to begin spending local again ndash creating cash flow for businesses worst hit by the pandemic.The idea was drawn up by thinktank the Resolution Foundation ndash who suggest a one-year time limit for spending the money.What is the idea Under the scheme, every adult would be handed pound and every child given pound ndash with the payments restricted to lsquoface-to-facersquo retail and hospitality, instead of online.They would be universal, delivered as coupons, smartcards or even redeemable using mobile phones.The one-off paymentswould cost the UK Government around poundbillion.Its hoped the scheme could boost retail sectors post-lockdownWhy is it needed James Smith, at the Resolution Foundation, said there has been ldquohuge implications for sectors like retail, tourism and leisure.He said: ldquoThat is why the jobs of so many workers in these sectors are in the firing line. The Chancellorrsquos recovery package on Wednesday should reflect this unique economic challenge."As well as setting out the biggest ever peacetime job support programme, the Chancellor should get Britain spending in places where itrsquos needed most."A universal lsquoHigh Street Voucherrsquo scheme ndash worth pound per adult and pound per child ndash to be spent only in these sectors would kickstart demand in the right parts of our economy, boost living standards and deliver targeted support to the businesses that need help the most."The Chancellor has already shown that big, bold measures like the Job Retention Scheme are welcome and necessary in the current economic climate. He should take this same approach as we enter the crucial recovery phase of the crisis."You can view the full plans here.Will it happen ndash and when The UK Government has yet to comment on the plans.Official word could come as early as tomorrow, when Chancellor Rishi unveils new measures to protect the economy ndash however he has so far refused to speculate on whether the scheme could be implemented.He is expected to announce additional support for trainee and apprenticeship schemes, as well as a stamp duty ldquoholiday to support the housing industry.

title: youtube-cook-excited-borders-book-festival-debut
story: COOKING sensation Suzanne Mulholland canrsquot believe her luck at being a guest at the Borders Book Festival.Itrsquos an event the Ettrick Valley resident has attended for years.Mrs Mulholland, , is now excited about gracing the festivalrsquos virtual stage with her book The Batch Lady, a name by which she is possibly more famously known.She started her YouTube channel nearly three years ago, using it to share the benefits of what is known as batch cooking ndash a practice many householders know very well as they juggle work, childcare and home management.Her social media channels now have more than , followers, and she has appeared in the pages of The Sunand Daily Mail, as well as on ITVrsquos This Morning.But lockdown has seen her following grow even further, as shopping and cooking habits have changed, and the necessity to be canny with food has grown.ldquoBatch cooking is really prevalent at the moment, says Mrs Mulholland, ldquobased on everybodyrsquos shopping habits all of a sudden changing.ldquoPeople are shopping less and buying more, so gone are the days when people were shopping maybe every two to three days, nipping in and grabbing stuff.ldquoNow, people are going once a week, for a weekly shop. Wersquore seeing the amount that theyrsquore spending increasing, and theyrsquore buying a lot more but less often.Mrs Mulholland believes this trend will continue for some time, while shopping remains ldquoa feat.She says: ldquoYou have to stand in the queue outside, and wait your turn, and yoursquove got to think about the person standing two metres behind youhellipldquoEverybody all of a sudden needs to be a bit more organised and think in advance before they arrive at the shop.And with this decrease in shopping trips alongside a rise in the amount of groceries bought, there comes the quandary of use-by dates.ldquoThe sell-by dates nowadays are quite short, Mrs Mulholland says. ldquoTheyrsquore not allowing that your chicken is going to last to the end of the week, so itrsquos getting some of those meals prepped and put in the freezer, so come the end of the week, you can pull it out and itrsquos as fresh as the day you bought it.ldquoThe Batch Lady was set up, says Mrs Mulholland, with the aim of helping busy, working people ndash who either love cooking or hate it ndash to avoid the drudgery of producing daily family meals by preparing in advance.And she lives by this method herself. With the local shop a -minute drive away, Mrs Mulholland spends just half an hour in the shop itself, picking up her ingredients, ing home to cook the weekrsquos meals in roughly an hour, then freezing them and pulling one out each evening.Itrsquos a method that comes naturally to the business graduate and former time-management trainer.ldquoIrsquom about being very organised and getting mundane tasks done," she says. "Itrsquos always been my ethos. When I found myself on a rural farm [with husband Peter and children Jake, , and Zara, ], I realised that quite a lot of those things that I was teaching in a corporate environment resonated in the home le.,params: .pushAnd having answered her mum friendsrsquo requests to put her skills up on YouTube, she then got a call from HarperCollins offering a book deal ndash and the exciting opportunity to join her favourite book festival.Mrs Mulhollandrsquos three-book deal saw the first, The Batch Lady, published in March this year the second will be published next year but, in the meantime, her publisher suggested what would help in lockdown would be a ldquoplanner book ndash The Batch Lady Meal Planner ndashout on July .The book features  recipes, and guidance on how to meal plan and record manage freezer contents.And itrsquos the book she will share at this yearrsquos book festival, albeit online rather than in person.ldquoI was gutted, because the Borders Book Festival I go to every year ndash itrsquos right near my house, says Mrs Mulholland.ldquoI never miss it ndash Irsquove got a four-day ticket usually. And I was desperate to go to it, so Irsquom now doing the online version.ldquoItrsquos really special. I was so pleased to be an author finally and to be going to it as an author.The festival is not the only event Mrs Mulholland will be guesting at this year but it is the most important to the local YouTube star.ldquoThe Borders Book Festival was at the top of my list because itrsquos my local one."Itrsquos always so amazing that we have all these big authors come to the Borders, so that was why I really wanted to be in it. Irsquom a Borders girl!The video and live chat will be available on the Borders Book Festivals website at pm on July .

title: alexander-hamilton-scottish-roots-disney-sensation
story: HE is remembered in history as one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and, more recently, his story has been brought to le in a Broadway show.Butdid you know Alexander Hamilton, the face of the  bill, could trace his family history back to a castle ruin on the outskirts ofStevenston, North Ayrshire George Washingtons right hand man and the inspiration behind one of the most successful shows of all-time has been thrust back into the spotlightin recent days after Lin-Manuel Mirandas musical made its way onto streaming service Disney+.During his le, Hamilton became an influential interpreter and promoter of theU.S. Constitution, as well as the founder of the politys financial system, theFederalist Party, theUnited States Coast Guard, and theNew York Postnewspaper.George WashingtonAs the firstSecretary of the Treasury, Hamilton was the main author of the economic policies of Washingtons administration.He played a crucial role in laying the foundations of the America we know today, before he was shot dead at just the age byAaron Burr in a duel.At this point you might be wondering what exactly this has to do with Scotland Well,it doesnt take long for Hamiltons Scottish roots to be mentioned in the eponymous show, which opens: "How does a b****d, orphan, son of a w***e , and a Scotsman, dropped in the middle of a forgotten spot in the Caribbeanby providence, impoverished, in squalor, grow up to be a hero and a scholar "Hamilton, son of a Scotsman from Ayrshire, grew up on the West Indian island of Nevis . Given the lyrics to the shows opening, youve probably already guessed he had to endure a dficult upbringing.His father, James Hamilton, was the fourth son of the Laird of Grange, also named Alexander. He moved to the Caribbean instead of pursuing an education at the University of Glasgow like his brothers.It was there, itrsquos thought, on January , , that his son Alexander was born, though the date is uncertain. Some scholars believe it was two years later.It was a birth out of wedlock, explaining a later remark from President John Adams, who once described him as ldquothe b*****d brat of a Scottish peddler. His father had an affair with Rachel Fawcett Lavien, who was of British and French Huguenot descent.It was to be a troubled childhood. His parents had a dficult relationship, though it lasted many years ndash he had a brother born two years before him. His father deserted the family forcing Hamilton to take his first job at the age of  to help make ends meet. The death of his mother left him abandoned and orphaned aged just  in .Taken in by an older relative and thereafter by a local merchant, the young man soon began to excel in commerce and trade. Such was his evident talent that businessmen soon pooled funds to send him to America for an education.,params: .pushHe made swt progress in the US, devoting time to writing about politics. One report says he left the college he was attending to report on the Boston Tea Party, the first big revolt against the British.Alexander Hamilton is regarded as one of Americas Founding Fathers By  hersquod garnered many battle honours and attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. This brought him to the attention of Washington, who appointed him his assistant and trusted adviser.After the war, he graduated in law and commenced practice at the Bar in New York where he was a prominent figure. However, it was in politics and government that he was to excel and leave his real legacy. Influential in the drafting of the US Constitution, he was a delegate for New York and wrote the Federalist Papers.He remains the arch Federalist in the arguments that have raged on down through the years between state and federal rights.When Washington was elected President, he appointed Hamilton First Secretary of the Treasury.Plenty more was still to come for the lad with Ayrshire in his blood, until he was killed by Burr in .His legacy, however, lives on in wallets across America and TV screens around the world.

title: everyone-scotland-can-get-free-pint-tennents-next-week
story: EVERYONE of drinking age in Scotland can get a free pint of lager from Tennentrsquos to mark the reopening of pubs across the country.Hundreds of thousands of complimentary pints of Tennentrsquos Lager and Tennentrsquos Light will be waiting at  premises across the country.It comes as beer gardens welcome visitors after  weeks of lockdown and bars could reopen with social distancing on July .Kenny Gray, managing director at Tennentrsquos, said: ldquoFor the last  years, Tennentrsquos Lager has been dedicated to Scotland and proud to serve the freshest, quality pints to pubs and drinkers across the country.ldquoFrom moments with friends and family to birthdays, holidays, anniversaries and graduations, the list of things wersquove all missed during this dficult period is endless and we know that going to the pub ranks highly.ldquoAfter work drinks, cosy pub lunches and memorable nights out with friends have all been put on hold for nearly four long months.ldquoBut we can now finally look forward to celebrating these important milestones once again while creating new ones ndash and what better way to welcome everyone back than by dedicating a pint of Tennentrsquos Lager or Tennentrsquos Light to Scotland How can I claim my pint Drinkers can claim online atTennentsdedicatedtoyou.#

title: take-rubbish-home-scots-beauty-spots-swamped-litter-lockdown-eases
story: Scots are being urged to help avoid selfish, irresponsible behaviour which has seen beauty spots across the country swamped with litter and human waste as lockdown restrictions ease.Government agencies, campaigners and environmental experts have come together to issue a joint plea for people to act responsibly as restrictions ease further throughout Scotland.In the last few weeks, Scots have been allowed to venture further from their homes as part of the Scottish Governments route map out of lockdown.But some tourist hotspots have seen their landscapes and environments marred by a barrage of litter and human waste.Forestry and Land Scotland has reminded members of the public that while many car parks and beauty spots are now open, waste collection services may not be operational.Chief executiveSimon Hodgson said:ldquoAs Scotland gets re-accustomed to travelling further afield for leisure pursuits, we are appealing to the public to help avoid repeats of the selfish, irresponsible behaviour that over the past few weeks has seen many sites swamped by litter ndash or even despoiled by human waste.ldquoThis sort of anti-social behaviour not only creates a signicant health hazard but also eats in to the limited resources that land managers have at their disposal.ldquoWe would urge people to first of all think carefully about their travel plans, and secondly to behave like people who are proud to be able to call such a beautul country home: donrsquot visit sites until they are open and take your litter home.Mr Hodgson added:ldquoThe sad thing is, many of the people responsible for the littering would say they were proud to live in Scotland, and yet as we have seen over the past few weeks, they treat our beautul countryside in this contemptible manner. Itrsquos not acceptable.The call has been backed by Zero Waste Scotland, Keep Scotland Beautul, Scottish Water, Loch Lomond  The Trossachs National Park Authority, Scottish Natural Heritage and Cairngorms National Park Authority.Recent incidents have seen people charged after damaging national parks and culpable and reckless conduct across Scotland.Between Friday, July  and Sunday, July , more than  people were chargedwith breaches of the Loch Lomond andTheTrossachs National Park Camping Management Bylaws.Broken glass, bin bags of rubbish and sleeping bags were left littered across the park.In some areas, irreparable fire damage was caused to trees and the ground.Nineteen bags of litter were collected from a single site, with another site wielding a further ten.Iain Gulland, chief executive atZero Waste Scotland, said: ldquoWith limited access available to activities and facilities, our areas of beauty are more important than ever before for people to enjoy some exercise and fresh air."We are fortunate to live in such a wonderful country and ask people not to spoil the enjoyment of everyone .ldquoPeople who litter are committing a criminal offence, are often risking our safety and polluting our environment."There are no excuses - you take it out with you, bin it or take it home when you are done.

title: major-changes-scotlands-shielding-population-week----need-know
story: THE Health Secretary has today revealed the easing of measures for people shielding in Scotland during lockdown.Initially, the Scottish Government asked people to shield until July  but stated that there would be periodical easing of restrictions throughout July.But during the daily coronavirus briefing today, Jeane Freeman confirmed a number of changes ndash which will take place from Friday.What will change From Friday, those who are shielding will no longer require to distance themselves from those they live with.Those in single-parent households or who live on their own will also be able to form an extended household group in the same way as the rest of the population can, including being able to visit someone in their home or stay overnight without having to socially distance.Ms Freeman also said that those who are in this category will also be able to book holiday accommodation or go to a second home, provided these do not have shared facilities with other households.However, the Health Secretary ldquostrongly advised that this is only done with people in the same household or as part of an extended household.The Health Secretary also said that those who are shielding will be able to meet up with people from two households outdoors, in the same way as the rest of the population, as well as go inside to use the toilet.What did the Health Secretary say #Ms Freeman said: ldquoI hope the changes that we have announced and those that I hope will continue to come will help to ease what I know has been an extraordinary burden that shielding has placed on you over the past few months.ldquoI canrsquot say enough to express how grateful I am to you for following the advice. It has been stressful, I know at times it has felt frightening and I know at times it has felt restrictive.ldquoRight now we can begin to ease those restrictions because of the falling infection rate. Right nowyou follow these precautions our clinical advisers tell us that the risk of you catching the virus is low ndash that is very dferent from the beginning of the pandemic, as well you know.ldquoI hope that you are able to resume much more of your lives than you have been advised to be able to do in the last few months.Letters will be sent to people in the shielding category from Thursday, Ms Freeman said.

title: nicola-sturgeon-reacts-border-telegraph-investigation
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has spoken about the Border rsquosinvestigation into patient transfers during the coronavirus pandemic.NHS Borders moved dozens of hospital patientsinto care homes without checking whether the patients had COVID-.The health board was not breaching Scottish Government guidance at the time.Asked about the transfers, the First Minister said it is ldquoimportant to note that NHS Bordersbelieves the transfers did not spread the virus.Ms Sturgeon also criticised Borders MP John Lamont for his accusationthat the transfers show ldquohow negligent the SNP were on care homes.When that allegation was put to her, the SNP leader said: ldquoPart of me wants to treat that comment with the contempt it deserves.Ms Sturgeonrsquos comments came during her televised press conference today , with ITV Borderrsquos political editor Peter MacMahon among the journalists posing questions.Mr MacMahon asked Ms Sturgeon to comment on this newspaperrsquos report - based on a Freedom of Information [FoI] request - that  Borders patients had been transferred to care homes without being tested before April .The First Minister said: ldquoIrsquove not seen the Border or the particular FoI so Irsquoll not comment too much on the detail of that.However, Ms Sturgeon did respond to Mr Lamontrsquos criticism of her government.She said the Toryrsquos remarks were ldquoan attempt to politicise something that is inappropriate".Going on to defend her handling of the pandemic response in Scotland, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWe had very dficult decisions to make.ldquoWe took those decisions on the best knowledge and evidence we had at the time."And wersquove had in place lots of things to protect care home residents.She added: ldquoThe death toll in care homes - and the death toll overall - has been awful and I would be the first person to acknowledge that and there will be lessons that we all have to learn from that.ldquoAnybody trying to make this an issue of party-politics should really take a long, hard look at themselves in the mirror.

title: make-diy-face-mask-using-just-t-shirt-hair-bobbles
story: FACE coverings are to become mandatory across all shops in Scotland as of tomorrow.Following the move to make the coverings compulsory on public transport, the First Minister argued that"as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."To help people along with the process, the Scottish Government has released a handy video on how to make your own face mask - using just a hair bobble or rubber band and a T-shirt.Watch how to make your own DIY mask below:From Friday  July, you will be required by law to wear a face covering when you go into a shop. Face coverings are already mandatory on all public transport.Some exemptions apply, which you can read about at https:t.co uCivwyYlLearn how to make your own ## pic yGmXylLrmdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced From tomorrow,the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, Ms Sturgeon said.

title: buy-scottish-island-iconic-loch-lomond-inchconnachan-island-goes-sale
story: During lockdown, some Scots have been basking in the opportunity to enjoy some much needed alone time.Now, those enjoying the solitude can take their privacy one step further with an entirely private Scottish island all to themselves.An island off the western shore of southern Loch Lomond is to be launched on the market, boasting private, secluded bays and ancient woodland.Inchconnachanhas been in the ownership of the Colquhoun family since the th century but uninhabited for the last  years.Now, it is set to go on the market for offers of more than pound,.The island is only accessible by boat from the shores of Luss, andis home to some of the best wildle the country has to offer.Inchconnachanrsquos ancient oak woodland and secluded bays attract otters and deer, along with a wide iety of birds including the endangered capercaillie and the occasional pair of nesting ospreys.The island is both an Area of Special Scientic Interest and a Special Area of Conservation as well as being part of the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.Surrounded by a beautul backdrop of mountain ranges, including Ben Lomond, the island is currently home to a derelict Colonial-style timber bungalow dating from the s, reputedly built by retired tea merchant Admiral Sullivan in the style of an Indian tea plantation bungalow.Butyou want a little more luxury, planning consent and detailed architectural drawings have been obtained to replace the existing bungalow with a new four-bedroom lodge and one-bedroom wardenrsquos house, along with a boathouse and pier.Cameron Ewer for Savills said: ldquoThis is an extraordinary opportunity to acquire a beautul and completely private, yet accessible, retreat and create a wonderful new residence there."For those seeking peace and seclusion, yet wanting all that this part of Scotland has to offer in the way of nature and water-based sport and activities, this is surely the ultimate prize.Tom Stewart-Moore for Knight Frank said: ldquoTo be able to build your own house on your own private island but yet in a very accessible and beautul part of the country will be a dream for many and is likely to have global appeal.

title: borders-recycling-centres-need-know-july-13
story: RECYCLING centres will ditch their number-plate entry system on Monday .During lockdown, sites in the Borders had restricted access to drivers depending on whether their number plate has an odd or even number.But Scottish Borders Councilhas announced it is dropping the system, extending opening hours and accepting kerbside rubbish.From Monday, the centres will open at am on weekdays and close at .pm, with weekends am-.pm.As was the case before the pandemic, the sites will be closed on one day a week .SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "We are now at a stage where the majority of waste types are being accepted. ldquoThe next step as part of the phased recovery is to change the operating hours back to what they were before lockdown."This will increase the number of hours sites are open each day.ldquoIt will also signicantly reduce the number of staff that are required to support the current operating model.ldquoThis will assist the councils wider recovery plan allowing support staff toto their normal jobs."All sites will close between .pm and pm to allow staff to take a lunch break.Some regulations will remain in place, including: a maximum of five bags of waste at a time are to be brought to any centre only one person per household should travel to a recycling centre and no trailers or horse-boxes will be accepted.Opening hours are as follows:Weekdays:middot Morning: .am - .pmmiddot Afternoon: .pm - .pmWeekend:middot Morning: .am - .pmmiddot Afternoon: .pm - .pmWeekday closures:middot Duns - Thursdaymiddot Eshiels- Wednesdaymiddot Eyemouth - Tuesday and Fridaymiddot Galashiels - Tuesdaymiddot Hawick - Wednesdaymiddot Kelso - Mondaymiddot Selkirk - Monday and Friday

title: hairdressers-scotland-reopen-week----changes-expect
story: THE date for hairdressers and barbers to reopen in Scotland has been revealed.Speaking in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed a number of lockdown measures would be eased across the country as we moved into Phase .Among the eagerly anticipated dates announced for reopening - which generated laughter in Parliament - is that of hairdressers and barbers.Ms Sturgeon confirmed this isfrom July .Personal retail services, such as beauticians and tailors, can reopen with enhanced hygiene measures from July .Here, we outline some of the changes that will likely face you at the hairdressers:What changes will there be inside The British Beauty Councilhas outlined a number of suggested guidelines for social distancing and hygiene within hairdressers and salons.They suggest, among other advice, the following:Staff members are to wear personal protective equipmentand a disposable apron.Disposable towels and disposable paper gowns to be used rather than machine washed ones.To erect Perspex screens throughout the salon area, including the till area, backwash stations and hairdresser chairs to help limit the spread of infection.Will I have to wear a mask According to the British Beauty Council, clients are to ldquobring their own PPE unless employers decide to supply.Currently, it looks like it will be a matter for each inidual salon to decide ndash but going on that advice it is probable you will have to wear a face covering.What  might change Some hairdressers may opt to extend their opening hours ndash meaning staff can see clients but have fewer people inside at any one time.As with supermarkets, the British Beauty Council recommends a ldquovulnerable hour first thing, once the salon has been deep-cleaned from the previous day.It may also be harder to get an appointment, with extreme demand following lockdown and the need for an extra  minutes to be allocated for cleaning between clients.Many places will only allow pre-bookings, not walk-ins, and advance payments over the phone would be encouraged.Indoor waiting areas could also be scrapped, with customers having to wait outside until being called in at the time of their appointment.Will it cost more As expected, this might be the case.A note on the British Beauty Council website reads: ldquoIt may be advisable to raise prices to cover cost of PPE, longer opening hours, sanitisation and hygiene equipment, reduced appointments and other accrued costs as a result of COVID-.

title: ryanair-virgin-among-worst-travel-firms-refunds-coronavirus
story: Virgin, Love Holidays and Ryanair are some of the worst travel firms for offering holiday refunds during the coronavirus pandemic, according to a survey forMoneySavingExpert.Brits were essentially banned from travelling abroad for over  days, meaning many people had to cancel their holiday plans.During this time, millions of people have been owed refunds for holidays they couldnrsquot go on - but the MoneySavingExpery survey suggests that not every travel firm has treated their customers the same.Results of the surveyThe survey ran between  June and  July and received , responses. The aim was to find out how people felt about their lsquorefund experiencersquo and whether they actually got one.Three big names did particularly poorly. Ryanair scoredthe worst of the major brands with a net score of -%. It wasjoined by Virginand Love Holidays .Unsurprisingly these three firms were also among the worst in refunding with just % of Ryanair, Virgin Holidays and Love Holidays customers saying they hadreceived a refund to date.A majority of Virgin Atlantic and Ryanair customers said they hadbeen waiting more than two months for a refund since first asking.Alpharooms was rated the overall worst for customer experience and refunds, with a net score of -%. Not one of customers surveyed said they received a refund.However, not every travel firm has performed badly during the pandemic.A total of % of Jet and Jet Holidays customers who had bookings cancelled said theyreceived a refund.Trailfinders and Airbnb customers were also likely to get a refund, with % and % respectively saying they hadbeen refunded.lsquoIt is time for regulators and politicians to take actionrsquoMartin Lewis, founder ofMoneySavingExpert,has been outspoken about the refund issue throughout the pandemic.He said that the ldquorefund farce and has left people in distress and ldquosome have seen their mental health impacted by it.He added: "It is time for regulators and politicians to take action.ldquoEven now, after months, less than a third of people in our mammoth survey have received the fulllegally required refunds, and it simply isnrsquot good enough.ldquoWe will be passing a dossier on this to the Competition and Markets Authority , Civil Aviation Authority and Department for Transport."Of course, we understand the impact of the pandemic on the travel industry sector is devastating. Itrsquos why Irsquove long called for forbearance both ways ndashpeople can help by taking vouchers or rebooking then they should."Yet how inidual firms have treated their customers during this time will long be remembered. title: fancy-ride-trishaw-
story: BORDERS care home residents will soon have the chance to embrace the great outdoors again - by riding in three-wheeled e-bikes.Volunteers in Hawick set up the townrsquos Cycling Without Agescheme last year.The project involves cyclists jumping in specially-adapted e-bikes - which can carry two passengers - and offering free rides to people who have mobility dficulties.Volunteer Keith Irving said: ldquoThis is a great project because it allows many who used to be able to explore Hawick get another chance to experience the sights.The charitable organisation CWA began in Denmark, but it has become international - and Scotland itself now boasts  electric trishaws.Hawick received two bikes in September and the townrsquos first passengers were welcomed two months later.The official launch had been scheduled for this Easter, but COVID- put paid to those plans.Now, though, volunteers are readying themselves for ato the saddle - and they look forward to rides around Wilton Lodge Park.People living in care homes or sheltered housing are being encouraged to contact the group.Anyone with mobility problems is also being urged to get in touch.Volunteer Jim McPherson said: ldquoThis is a dferent way to give mobility-limited people who are stuck inside a new view.ldquoOne lady who we took out said she had not seen the park in over six years and was amazed at the change.ldquoIt is truly a great feeling to help people experience the pleasure of cycling around the park.He added: "Right now, everyone in the Hawick chapter has a feeling of real frustration at the current situation, having put in a lot of time and effort.ldquoWe are unable to make use of the trishaws as wed previously planned.ldquoBut weve had fantastic support from the Hawick community, with many groups and iniduals having helped us to raise the money to get two trishaws in a record time.ldquoAnd we really want to be able to pay back this support and get back out in the park and where in Hawick.Currently, there are six trained volunteers and a further three awaiting training.Training includes PVG checks, instructions on how to use the e-bikes, and guidance on the safety checks involved with loading and unloading clients.The trishaws combine an electric bicycle with a passenger compartment fit for two at the front. A hood can be unfolded quicklythe weather turns wet.Each ride lasts between  minutes and an hour.Hawick is not the only Borders town which takes part in the scheme - the Peebles group has been running since .The Hawick chapter, which hopes to get a third trishaw, is inviting contact from potential volunteers and clients. The phone number is   and the Facebook page is: www.facebook cwasHawick

title: joy-scottish-bookmakers-scottish-government-agrees-lift-restrictions-betting-shops
story: BOOKMAKERS in Scotlandare celebrating after the Scottish Government agreed to lt a number of restrictions placed on betting shops.The shops were allowed to reopen their doors onJune  for the first time since the COVID- lockdown.But unlike in the rest of the UK, the shops were ordered to remove all of their chairs, switch off their gaming machines and not show any live racing on TV.chief executive Michael Dugher " alt"Border : Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher " class"editor-image"Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher As a result, turnover in some shops slumped by  per cent as customers either stayed away or crossed the border to England to put on a bet.Industry bosses warned that unless the restrictions were lted, shops could be forced to close and staff made redundant.Following a campaign by the Betting and Gaming Council, it has now been confirmed that from July , the restrictions will no longer apply.However, the shops will still follow strict anti-COVID measures, with customers being encouraged to apply sanitiser and follow social-distancing rules.BGC chief executive Michael Dugher said: ldquoThis is great news for Scotlandrsquos  betting shops and the , hardworking staff that they employ.ldquoWe have always said that the extra restrictions imposed on Scottish betting shops were unnecessary."We are delighted that the Scottish Government has listened and responded.ldquoBetting shops in Scotland can now look forward to playing their part in helping to kickstart the economy, supporting Scottish racing and providing a safe environment for customers who enjoy a flutter.

title: foreign-office-says-uk-residents-avoid-cruises
story: CORONAVIRUS has caused travel mayhem this year, forcingmany UK residents to cancel or postpone their holidays.While travelling abroad is now permitted, theof cruise holidays isnrsquot likely to be on the cards any time soon.Am I allowed to go on a cruise holiday The UK Foreign and Commonwealth Officeissued a statement onJuly  advising UK holidaymakers to avoid travelling on cruise ships due to the pandemic.It reads: ldquoThe Foreign and Commonwealth Office advises against cruise ship travel at this time.ldquoThis is due to the ongoing pandemic and is based on medical advice from Public Health England.ldquoThe government will continue to review its cruise ship travel advice based on the latest medical advice.ldquoIf you have future cruise travel plans, you should speak to your travel operator, or the travel company you booked with, for further advice.ldquoThe Foreign and Commonwealth Office continues to support the Department for Transportrsquos work with industry for the resumption of international cruise travel.Previous advice issued by the FCO on March  said that British nationals aged seven and above, as well as those with underlying health conditions, should not travel on cruise ships.What does it mean for planned holidays The updated travel advice means that many who have future holidays booked on a cruise ship risk having their trips cancelled or postponed.Responding to the update, Rory Boland, editor of consumer magazine Which  Travel, said"The FCOs advice against cruise ship travel will lead to most upcoming cruises being cancelled or postponed."Most cruise holiday customers should be legally entitled to a cash refund within  days under the package travel regulations, but as weve seen across the travel industry recently, operators facing a surge in refund claims are often taking longer tocustomers money to them."If refunds will be delayed, cruise companies must urgently let customers know and give a clear timetable for when money will be ed."The FCO should also extend its warning to include a definitive date, to give operators and customers clarity over when it will be safe to rebook."PO Cruises, the biggest cruise line in the UK, has suspended all of its sailings until mid-October.

title: wetherspoons-slashes-pint-prices-1-29-reduces-cost-meals
story: Pub chain Wetherspoons isto slash the prices of its drinks and meals following a cut in VAT on the hospitality sector by the UK government.The cuts were announced last week by the Chancellor Rishi Sunak in an attempt to ease economic pressurescaused by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown.VAT for the hospitality sector was cut from  per cent to five per cent, and Wetherspoons has said that it will pass the savings directly on to customers.Menus featuring a grinning Chancellor alongside messages labelled "Sunaks specials" and "Dishi Rishi" boast cut-price deals on food and drink with a pint of beer costing as little as pound..When will the deals start The deals will come into force from Wednesday, July , with real ale, coffee, soft drinks, breakfasts and other food among the discounted items.The VAT cut doesnrsquot apply to alcohol, but Wetherspoon has said it will cut the price of ales in reaction to savings made where.A pint of Ruddles Bitter now costs just pound., down from its pre-cut price of pound., while the price of a pint of Doom Bar has been slashed from pound. to pound..A traditional breakfast will cost pound. - a saving of p. A burger and soft drink is down to pound..Soft drinks will be cut by p, down to pound. for a oz glass.The deals will be in place at  of its pubs.Prices for real ale will be up to pound higher at the companyrsquos other  pubs across the UK which are located in major town and city centres, airports and stations.However, these pubs will have price reductions of at least  pence per drink and  pence per meal.What hasWetherspoons said Wetherspoon chairman Tim Martin called on the move to be made permanently.He said:"Wetherspoon has campaigned for tax equality between pubs, restaurants and supermarkets for many years. Supermarkets pay no VAT on food sales and pubs pay  per cent."Supermarkets pay about two pence per pint of business rates and pubs pay about  pence."These tax dferences have helped supermarkets to subsidise their selling prices of beer, wine and spirits, enabling them to capture about half of pubs beer sales, for example, in the past  years."A VAT reduction will help pubs and restaurants reverse this trend - creating more jobs, helping high streets and eventually generating more tax income for the Government."lsquoNeverspoonsrsquo appWetherspoons has been widely criticised during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly for Tim Martinrsquos actions regarding furloughing staff. An app launched in recent weeks advises pubgoers to avoid the high street chain.The Neverspoons app highlights local independent pubs close to Wetherspoon venues.App developerShane Jonessaid:"The whole premise is, Wetherspoons is a massive chain and they dont need as much help.

title: three-simple-tips-stop-glasses-fogging-wearing-face-masks
story: A HELPFUL optician has revealed some simple tips on how glasses wearers can keep their lenses clear while using a face mask.Last week, the Scottish Government made it a legal requirement to wear coverings in shops - making the use of them a lot more widespread.It comes following the decision to make them mandatory on public transport - with the First Minister saying there has been "close to%" compliance with the new rules.But a number of Scots have been struggling to manage the masks, stating it causes their glasses to steam or fog up.Canny believe a need to pick between breathing or seeing pic VxpHumCgmdash #July , Following the latest move,Gordon Kyle, fromMiller and McClure Opticians in Paisley, shared his three top tips to avoid steaming up your lenses.He said: "Ive seen it a lot where peoples glasses are fogging up - there are a few things to think about"Here are the three tips:Mask behind glassesGordon suggests keeping the glasses on top of the mask, which acts almost as a seal keeping the mask tight to the top of the cheeks without pushing air towards the lenses.Tissue paperThe optician suggested lining the top of the mask with tissue paper before putting it on. In his video, this almost completely stops any fog taking place.Tie a knotGordons third tip was to tie the mask on the string so it sits "almost like a package". By doing this, the mask sits in a nicer shape where the air is being pushed away from the glasses.Watch the explainer video here:What  The optician joked that anyone with contact lenses should consider using them.Speaking to the Daily Record, he also advised against lining the lenses with household items, as seen online.He said:ldquoThere has been chatonlineabout using shaving foam, toothpaste and even methylated spirits but my concern is that it could cause long-term damage to the lenses.ldquoThe other thing folk have mentioned for the lenses is washing-up liquid. Irsquom just not convinced that itrsquos risk free."

title: alexandra-shulman-former-vogue-boss-talks-fashion-books
story: ALEXANDRA Shulman is hugely disappointed not to have been able to visit the Borders Book Festival in person last month.The former Vogueeditor-in-chief, who spent  years at the helm of the fashion bible, had been due to visit Melrose for a chat about her latest book, Clothes... And Other Things That Matter, until the coronavirus lockdown forced the physical events cancellation."I am so sad that Im not coming this year," Ms Shulman tells theBorder ."It would have been great to physically be there."It might not be the same as having her with us in the Borders, but viewers of her chat, which will be shown on July , will still be able to watch her share her thoughts on the fashion industry, her love of reading and the role of the bra in social history...Even better, theyll be able to ask questions of the author herself at the end of the talk ndash something Ms Shulman is very much looking forward to."I always like talking to the audience and hearing what questions they have," she says."Its not the same as being there. When lockdown first happened and I realised everything was going to be cancelled, it was a depressing moment."But you realise you have dferent ways of talking about [the book] and I hope that next year, when the paperbacks out, Ill be able to get back and do all these events live."The globally renowned journalist might not be able to make it to the Borders but she will be spending more time north of the border as she visits Atterley, the online fashion boutique with whom she has been appointed strategic advisor, at its headquarters in Edinburgh.She says: "Ive only just started working with them so my contact has been via Zoom so far but Im hoping to get up and meet the team in the next month or so."Also, my stepson works at the university in Edinburgh, and lives in Edinburgh so Im keen to get up and see him a bit more, too."While Ms Shulman is no longer moving in Voguecircles, it seems she will never cease to be immersed in fashion, whether its clothes as statement or as a form of identity.She spent two years writing Clothes..., a book that is part memoir, part fashion history.She says of it: "What I wanted was to write a book that wasnt so much about clothes, per se, but how they relate to the other things that you have strong feelings about in your le."How you dress for dferent phases in your le and how everybodys wardrobe is a treasure trove of memories."You have stuff in there that youve had for years, that you probably never wear but you dont want to get rid of because it reminds you of something, or a part of your le, something of yourself, that it encapsulates."This idea of saving and reusing clothes is very popular now ndash reduce, reuse, recycle.What does Ms Shulman say of fast fashion ndash the production of cheap clothing by poorly treated work forces "In the book I write about it, the idea of the kind of glamour I always felt was attached to the secondhand clothes I loved as a teenager. It was all rag bags from charity shops and markets."And then it stopped throughout the late s, s and early s, and now, in the last  years or so, the idea of secondhand and recycling has been growing more traction in terms of fashion."She goes on: "But then came in this huge imperative to be more environmentally sound, ecologically sound, and looking at sustainability, so thats all come together to be a very big movement in fashion."I think the most important thing is the production lines. I dont think that we all necessarily want to wear secondhand clothes ndash I mean, I love finding a secondhand bargain somewhere its something I spend a lot of time doing ndash but a lot of people dont like that idea and the important thing is not that you wear clothes that somebody  has owned before but that the fabrics are recycled and we look at how a circular economy works in fashion."Ms Shulman believes very strongly that the drive for more sustainable fashion must come from the brands themselves."It has to be driven by the brands, the people making the clothes," she says."Theres a much harsher environment now for people who arent watching out for good practice."And that will extend to the production of the clothes but its not yet at a point where you have to prove that youve got a sustainable pipeline.,params: .push"And, at the end of the day, a big driver for people is what they can afford."But, of course, its not only fashion fans but also book lovers who will be drawn to see Ms Shulman speak, and she talks just as passionately of her childhood love of reading as she does her favourite Chanel jackets."I loved reading, as a child. Loved it. I used to love Kay Thompsons Eloise."Eloise is a child who is brought up in the Plaza Hotel in New York, and she kind of wreaks havoc, going up and down escalators and letting her pet turtle skedaddle around the corridors. That was one of my favourite books."And Emil  The DetectivesI loved, as well."And all the schoolgirl books, like Mallory Towers... heavenly!"If you thought the last thing Ms Shulman would have done while running one of the worlds most successful magazines was read books, she insists its important to make time for such a pursuit."I always used to say to people who said to me, I dont know how you have time to read, I dont have any time to read ndash you do have time to read, you just dont choose to use your time reading."If you really wanted to read, thats what youd do with your time."She adds: "I read a lot ndash I squeeze it in. This week Ive only read for a couple of hours but when I have got some time that isnt allocated to something , I will read."If you choose to make time to read Clothes..., youll be rewarded by a nostalgic travel through Ms Shulmans wardrobe timeline, interspersed with thoughts on the relationship between fashion and identity."I went through notebooks, diaries and photograph albums to try to dig up the feelings and the memories about certain clothes," she says, "but it wasnt totally nostalgic because I spent quite a lot of time also reading up about the history of ious objects and doing research so it wasnt just about myclothes."Its not a book that dishes about the famous people I met at Vogue. Its a personal memoir and a book about how clothes make us feel."To view the video and live chat on July , you can go to this address.

title: contaminated-sludge-found-borders-waste-water-site
story: BORDERS residents have been warned against tipping fats, oils and grease down the sink.It comes after Scottish Water discovered St Boswellsrsquo waste water site contaminated with used cooking oil.Alan Aitchison, of Scottish Water, said: "The amount of cooking oil which entered our works at St Boswells was signicant."We now have to empty and carry out extra cleaning of a number of tanks, and we will have to transport the contaminated sludge to Galashiels Waste Water Treatment Works where it will be disposed of and correctly treated, in a way which is non-harmful to the environment.When fats, oils and greaseare poured down a drain, they contribute to the build-up of fatbergs ndash congealed lumps of fats and non-biodegradable waste, such as baby wipes and sanitary items ndashwhich can cause internal and external flooding, as well as environmental damage.Mr Aitchison said: "Everything you dispose of down sinks and toilets will all end up in the drains and sewers ndash and we urge everyone to think twice about how they dispose of fats, oils, grease and other products such as wipes and cotton buds that arenrsquot biodegradable that can potentially lead to sewer blockages that will impact our water courses and environment."Mr Aitchison said the amount of oil found at the St Boswells treatment facility means a deep-clean is necessary.He added: "Toilet paper is the only biodegradable material that should be disposed into the sewer collection system ndash all other items should be bagged and binned for disposal."Scottish Water handles more than  burst pipes nationally per year, some of which are caused by FOGs.An FOG factfile has been created by Scottish Water:Fat, oil and grease may not appear harmful but as it cools it congeals and hardensThis can cause blockages to the inner lining of drainage pipes, which can lead to waste water flooding into gardens and properties and cause a health hazard to wildle and the local environmentIn extreme cases blocked sewers can spill into burns, rivers, streams, coastal waters and beaches which can cause environmental damageScottish Water deals with , blockages every year ndash at a cost of pound. million to attend and clearThe waste water drain which runs from your house to the public sewer is usually only about four inches wide - less than the diameter of a DVD.

title: preston-athletic-footballers-getting-bikes-good-causes
story: Members of Prestonpans-based Preston Athleticrsquos squad are getting on their bikes for a special fundraiser, which will see them visit the homes of  football teams in East Lothian, Edinburgh and Midlothian.Money raised will be split between the East of Scotland side and the NHS, as a thank you for the hard work of its staff.The cycle, had been due to take place last Saturday but was postponed to a still-to-be-confirmed new date, was the idea of team-mates Kai Austin and Nathan Stokes.Twenty-one-year-old Kai, who plays right back for the side, said: ldquoA lot of clubs have been making signings and we knew Preston were struggling even to just keep going.ldquoI have seen where someone has cycled or driven to the  league grounds [in the Scottish Premiership to League Two].ldquoWe thought maybe it would be a cool idea to do something like that at our level.ldquoWe came up with a challenge to entice people to want to donate and will us on.ldquoWe came up with visiting  grounds for  teams for the   season.The teammates plan to start at New Countess Park, home of Dunbar United.From there, it is on to Millfield , Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The cyclists will then head into Midlothian and tick off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Park , Ferguson Parkand Penicuik Park .Then it is into the Capital for stops at Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosure , Christie Gillies Park , Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand finally Peffermill .Finally, the weary cyclists willto East Lothian and tick off Olivebankbefore reaching the finish line and familiar surroundings of The Pennypit .In total, the cycle, which is about  kilometres , is expected to take upwards of seven hours, with the players stopping for a photograph at each ground.The fundraiser is also the latest step on the road to recovery for midfielder Nathan.The -year-old missed the entire   season after a horror ankle injury in pre-season, which saw ligaments ripped off the bone.Now, he is keen to get back to fitness ahead of the new campaign kicking off.He said: ldquoI have still been going to watch matches and getting the changing room banter.ldquoWe are all in a group chat and a lot of the boys have been working on their fitness throughout lockdown.ldquoThey have been out running or cycling and a lot of the boys are keen to get back to it and we are all missing it, especially myself.ldquoI am hoping to be back for next season.ldquoIt has been a long hard battle to get back fit after surgery.ldquoIt has been three months since surgery and the doctor and physio said it would be three to six months before I am back playing.Nathan, who previously played for Musselburgh Windsor and Ormiston, has played at most of the grounds but will tick off visiting Haddington, Newtongrange Star, Arniston Rangers and Civil Service Strollers during the cycle.He was looking forward to the fundraiser and was pleased with the reaction from members of the public, with more than pound already donated.He said: ldquoMy mum is a carer, Irsquove got family and friends who work in the NHS, so it is a no brainer to be honest.ldquoMyself and Kai said we should half the money with the NHS. The work they are doing just now is remarkable.To support the club, go to www.justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: social-enterprise-heavy-sound-finds-new-home-hub
story: The organisation, which champions community projects supporting the disadvantaged and young people, is moving into The Cockenzie Hub, formerly Cockenzie Business Centre, after taking on a three-year lease.The move will allow Heavy Sound, previously based in Tranent, to continue its work, with recent projects including refitting a bus with the help of prisoners at HMP Edinburgh, in Saughton, to create a mobile community centre.Heavy Sound uses rap, hip-hop, art and sports to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Jordan Butler, CEO of the organisation, said: ldquoFor the last five years we have been based in Tranent and, as a growing organisation, have found it dficult to find the right space in East Lothian to make a longer-term move.ldquoThe Cockenzie Hub is perfect for us we will be able to provide a full range of services as well as develop new programmes which will service Cockenzie and the wider community.The business hub was bought by Allied Surveyors Scotland on behalf of East Lothian-based Moscar LLP last October.Iain Mercer, of Allied Surveyors, welcomed the arrival of Heavy Sound to the hub.He said: ldquoThis underlines the demand for accommodation from local companies seeking affordable business space.

title: farewell-alfred-alf-tesoro
story: He died suddenly of a presumed heart attack at the age of , as he ed to his home in Eskside West after buying his daily newspaper on June .Due to current Covid- restrictions, a private service was conducted on Monday, June , at Inveresk Cemetery by Father Basil Clark, from Our Lady of Loretto Church on Newbigging, Musselburgh.The funeral cortegravege travelled along North High Street, passing his former cafe premises for the last time, to applause from members of the local community who lined the street to pay their respects.His niece Anita Cullinan said: ldquoOur family were truly touched by all who turned up to witness Alfrsquos last journey through Musselburgh ndash people who perhaps personally knew Alf or who had grown up during the years the shop was open.ldquoWersquod like to thank them for turning out and for the deeply respectful applause as the cortegravege passed by.Alf was born in the house above the shop on  North High Street on July , , the middle child of Edoardo Tesoro and Zelinda Costa Tesoro, whose other two children were Eolanda and Bert.Edoardo started the cafe known as A.Tesoro in , and his brother Emilio also started a Tesoro cafe across the bridge in Musselburgh around the same time. They married the Costa sisters, Zelinda and Carmen.Le was hard as Alfrsquos parents worked in the s through to the late s, with Zelinda looking after the children, maintaining a home and helping in the shop. They would have worked seven days a week, from dawn till dusk.Like most Italian immigrants of the time, they built the business from nothing to create a small ice cream factory behind the cafe.The ice cream was made by hand and boiled in small quantities each day in response to the demand. They didnrsquot have a pasteurising machine until after the Second World War, which then allowed larger quantities to be made and stored.Ice was delivered to the cafe each day and kept in a cool cabinet and the ice cream was then made using a secret family recipe, passing from father to son.The ice cream was then delivered by horse and cart to ious places around Portobello and Musselburgh and also distributed by bicycles with cool boxes in front to keep it fresh.They had young lads helping to distribute the ice cream and family members remember Alf saying that they also attended the Musselburgh Racecourse events and dance halls to expand the business.Alf started a car mechanicrsquos course on New Street, Musselburgh, before the war but hadnrsquot completed it before being called up to serve in the British Army as a private in the Argyll  Sutherland Highlanders Regiment.He served in both France and Germany, arriving in Normandy on June , , and spending the rest of the war in France, Holland and Germany.He ed to Musselburgh with the intention to finish his apprenticeship and learn how to drive but, as was so often the case with the eldest son of Italian families at the time, was asked by his father to run the business.His sister, Eolanda, had finished her secretarial studies after the war and met a young Italian called Ricardo Paganuzzi, who she married and who set up an ice cream business called Dinorsquos Cafe in Perth.His younger brother, Bert, went on to study law at the University of Edinburgh after he finished his national service.He married an Edinburgh girl called Catherine OrsquoDonnell, who studied to be a teacher.Alf therefore found himself the last of the siblings left in the business and stayed to continue work until his retirement ndash around  years.After he retired and, in the absence of successors to run the business, he sold up around  and continued to spend his remaining  or so years living very happily in his native Musselburgh.He travelled to the USA and to Canada but mainly spent his annual holidays with his nephew, Dino Paganuzzi, in Switzerland.He went on numerous trips back with Dino to where their family originated, Beverino, in the region of La Spezia in northern Italy, where relatives still live.He announced very shortly after ing from a family trip to Rome that his travelling days were now over, at the age of nearly .Alf was a member of the hiking club run by Our Lady of Loretto Catholic Church, where he seldom missed a Sunday Mass.He also spent many a Saturday at Easter Road in Edinburgh with his brother Bert, watching his beloved Hibs play football.Alf is survived by his nephew Dino Paganuzzi in Switzerland, niece Anita Cullinan, from Edinburgh, cousin Roland Toma, of the Cafe Continental in Gourock, cousin Elena Grippa in Rome, and their children.Many Musselburgh residents took to social media to pay tribute to Alf. Fiona Rutherford posted: ldquoLoved his cafe.Gillian Duffy said: ldquoAlways used to be the place to hang out at Alfiersquos when a teenager.Alan Fraser said: ldquoBrilliant recognition by the people of Musselburgh.Elaine Black added: ldquoHappy memories. The best ice cream.

title: walk-scott-foundation-boosts-waggonway-project
story: The project saw its crowdfunding campaign raise pound in just  hours as supporters backed its appeal for help.And the foundation offered to match the amount raised in tribute to its founder Scott Glynn, who was a keen supporter of the Waggonway.Karen Kidd, from the foundation, said: ldquoScott loved the Waggonway Project and wersquore delighted to be able to help with this funding.Ed Bethune, from the  Waggonway Heritage Group, said the project was facing challenges like so many other heritage organisations, as it moved into a third month of its museum ndash which is based on West Harbour Road, Cockenzie ndash remaining closed because of lockdown.The funds raised by the crowdfunding effort and from the foundation will help support the project during the tough current climate and into the future.Ed said: ldquoWersquore hugely grateful to the Walk With Scott Foundation for this incredible gesture at this time, which will help us bring the Waggonway Project through the current challenges and come out stronger on the other side.ldquoOur thanks go to all those who have donated, itrsquos a real example of the passion for local heritage and wersquore incredibly grateful for the support.The group is still fundraising via the JustGiving page and anyone wishing to donate can do so via justgiving crowdfunding waggonway

title: st-gabriels-rc-primary-schools-headteacher-deputy-retire
story: Anne Torley, who has been headteacher at St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School since , departed along with deputy Sue Adams, who had been at the school for  years.The double retirement was a fitting one for both women, as they first met at teacher training college in Edinburgh in the early s.Mrs Torley described Mrs Adams as her ldquoother half as she revealed they reconnected when she took the helm at St Gabrielrsquos ndash  years after they left St Andrewrsquos College of Education in Edinburgh ndash and became a close team.Praising Mrs Adams, Mrs Torley said: ldquoWe have had such fun pulling together an outstanding team.The retiring headteacher, who came to St Gabrielrsquos after nearly five years as headteacher of Ormiston Primary School, said she was leaving with many happy memories.And she urged pupils to keep up their positive attitudes during the coronavirus crisis, which meant she and Mrs Adams were unable to say goodbye in person.She said: ldquoIt is unfortunate but unavoidable that we cannot say a personal thank you andcongratulationsto all of our pupils at StGabrielrsquos ndash but we will not forget you.ldquoI would ask all of the children of StGabrielrsquos to keep up that positive attitude. I know you will do great things in the future.ldquoTake pride in how far you have come and have faith in how far you can go. Believe in yourselves and rememberhellip you can!Mrs Torley described leaving St Gabrielrsquos as a ldquobitter sweet time as she retires after  years as a teacher but said she was looking forward to new adventures.She said: ldquoStGabrielrsquos is very close to my heart but I am now looking forward to spending more time relaxing with my own family and learning new skills and having new adventures.She thanked the school community, saying: ldquoI am so very proud of the amazing and close-knit team we have become. Thank you also to the parents for their immense support over the years and to the local authority for making East Lothian such an attractive and worthwhile place to work.ldquoIt has been a privilege to work here, a fantastic journey, and I will hold many fond and special memories of you all.Mrs Adams also spoke of her pride in working at the school her daughters Rhianna and Josie attended.She said: ldquoStGabrielrsquos to me is part of my family. I joined the staff in  so Irsquove spent most of my adult le here. My daughters were pupils here ndash in fact, I taught them both.ldquoTherersquos something special about this school it pulls in special people, supportive parents and our staff teams have always had a close bond.ldquoAfter nearly  years Irsquove got to know a lot of pupils and itrsquos the big and small moments with the pupils that make you think, lsquoI am so lucky, I have had the best job in the worldrsquo.Eileen Rafferty, religious education advisor for the Archdiocese of St Andrewrsquos and Edinburgh, paid tribute to the retiring teachers.She said: ldquoSue and Anne always have childrenrsquos best interests at heart and have fostered a welcoming and inclusive school environment at St Gabrielrsquos.ldquoTheyrsquove done a sterling job and everyone in the Archdiocese wishes them a happy retirement.Margaret McBean, headteacher at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh, will serve as acting headteacher until a permanent replacement for Mrs Torley is found.

title: major-changes-scotlands-shielding-population-week----need-know
story: Initially, the Scottish Government asked people to shield until July  but stated that there would be periodical easing of restrictions throughout July.But during the daily coronavirus briefing today, Jeane Freeman confirmed a number of changes ndash that will take place from Friday.What will change From Friday, those who are shielding will no longer require to distance themselves from those they live with.Those in single parent households or who live on their own will also be able to form an extended household group in the same way as the rest of the population can, including being able to visit someone in their home or stay overnight without having to socially distance.Ms Freeman also said that those who are in this category will also be able to book holiday accommodation or go to a second home, provided these do not have shared facilities with other households.However, the Health Secretary ldquostrongly advised that this is only done with people in the same household or as part of an extended household.The Health Secretary also said that those who are shielding will be able to meet up with people from two households outdoors, in the same way as the rest of the population, as well as go inside to use the toilet.What did the Health Secretary say #Ms Freeman said: ldquoI hope the changes that we have announced and those that I hope will continue to come will help to ease what I know has been an extraordinary burden that shielding has placed on you over the past few months.ldquoI canrsquot say enough to express how grateful I am to you for following the advice. It has been stressful, I know at times it has felt frightening and I know at times it has felt restrictive.ldquoRight now we can begin to ease those restrictions because of the falling infection rate. Right nowyou follow these precautions our clinical advisers tell us that the risk of you catching the virus is low ndash that is very dferent from the beginning of the pandemic, as well you know.ldquoI hope that you are able to resume much more of your lives than you have been advised to be able to do in the last few months.Letters will be sent to people in the shielding category from Thursday, Ms Freeman said.

title: social-club-introduces-swipe-cards
story: Wallyford Miners Welfare and Social Club applied to East Lothian Licensing Board for permission to allow people to drink around its bowling green and create a new smoking area in an outdoor seating area.And its treasurer Darren Smith told the board of additional measures the club had taken to increase security, including  new CCTVcameras and an online system to let people know how busy the club is before heading out.Mr Smith told the board that the club had introduced a new entry system and planned to operate a closed door policy which would mean only members could access it, using their swipe cards.He said: ldquoMembers will be issued with swipe cards which will get them into the grounds and their information will be recorded.ldquoWe are also publishing a traffic light system on our website to let members know how busy we are.The club received praise from Councillor John McMillan, board member and East Lothian Provost, for its approach.He said he would be interested in a follow-up report on the success of the swipe card system and said the club was a central hub for the community.The board heard that the club, which applied for additional iations to its licence to allow children of all ages to attend s once they , hosted local community family events and was the only facility in the local area able to do so.Mr McMillan said: ldquoI have visited the club when it was supportinga community event.ldquoI was so impressed by the community feel and the way it was organised was very professional.The board approved changes to the clubrsquos licence to allow outdoor drinking and use of its main hall for s, as well as younger children to attend when restrictions allow for them to be held.

title: face-mask-tree-pops-front-garden
story: Debra Newlands was inspired to create her own face masks after buying ldquoawful versions online.Now, she is hanging the masks from the branches of a tree outside  Davidson Terrace, home to her son Luke Newlands, his partner Ashley Voy and her daughter Summer Deans, and encouraging people to buy one in exchange for a donation to Cancer Research UK.She said: ldquoWe did a pop-up tree on June  and I thought nobody would come round but it was really good.ldquoI have had a lot of people looking to order [the face masks] and that is how it came about.ldquoIt is a good way to protect the community against Covid- and raise some money for charity.ldquoWe picked Cancer Research UK because we lost a dear friend in March and it affects everybody.Since the middle of June, Debra, who works as a theatre nurse at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, estimates she has made  masks.Debra, , previously did ldquoa bit of dressmaking and called upon those skills again to create the masks.Materials have been ordered online while she has also visited Fabrication, on Haddington High Street, on a regular basis to get what she needed to make the facewear.People across the country have been using face masks while on public transport. Then, last week, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced it would be mandatory to wear them in shops from tomorrow .Debra, who lives on Haddingtonrsquos Acredales Walk, told the Courier: ldquoI had ordered some masks online for myself to start using going shopping.ldquoThey were awful and I thought I would make one.ldquoI went online and started looking at dferent patterns and things and tried a couple and made a few.ldquoWhile I was looking online, I came across an initiative which started down south called Community Mask Trees.The scheme was launched in Amesbury, near Salisbury, and has spread throughout the UK, with a handful of community mask trees in Scotland. Community mask trees are being created by volunteer sewers to provide free cloth face coverings to anyone who might need one.The pop-up Haddington Community Mask Tree takes place from am todayoutside the home on Davidson Terrace.Debra added: ldquoWe are asking for a donation of pound for an adult mask and pound for a child mask, and everybody has been happy to donate that.ldquoIn fact, some people have given more.ldquoIt costs around pound pound. to make each mask so Irsquove had to use some of it to buy fabric, etc, but we made pound profit from the first tree.

title: dunbars-lifeboat-crews-called-help-two-divers
story: Two female ers had travelled from Edinburgh and had earlier attempted a e at St Abbs, in the Scottish Borders.They then headed for Dunbar and began their exploration at .pm, just as the tide was at its highest, on Tuesday.A spokesman for Dunbar RNLI said: "Quickly, they experienced dficulties, with one fearing she was being carried further out than they intended."While a friend on shore called the Coastguard for help, the women removed their equipment and managed to get back to shore."Dunbars leboat crew was called out at .pm and were on the scene, close to the old pool below The Rocks Hotel, just seven minutes later.The crew checked the ers were unhurt and did not require medical treatment before then retrieving their ing equipment for them.Members of the towns Coastguard team also assisted the women from the shore.Gordon Kirkham, ILB helm, said: "The ers were well equipped and took sensible precautions by having someone keep an eye on them from the shore."They did the right thing by calling for help when they got into dficulties.UK Coastguard, who had also requested the all-weather leboatattend the incident, stood down both leboats before the ALB had launched from Torness.The in-shore leboat ed to Dunbar Harbour shortly before pm.If you see someone in trouble in the water dial  and ask for the Coastguard.

title: make-diy-face-mask-using-just-t-shirt-hair-bobbles
story: Following the move to make the coverings compulsory on public transport, the First Minister argued that"as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."To help people along with the process, the Scottish Government have released a handy video on how to make your own face mask - using just a hair bobble or rubber band and a T-shirt.Watch how to make your own DIY mask below:From Friday  July, you will be required by law to wear a face covering when you go into a shop. Face coverings are already mandatory on all public transport.Some exemptions apply, which you can read about at https:t.co uCivwyYlLearn how to make your own ## pic yGmXylLrHow will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced From tomorrow,the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.

title: celebrity-chefs-visit-east-lothian-new-tv-series
story: Chef Nick Nairn, who runs four restaurants, two cookery schools and has one Michelin star, and presenter Dougie Vipond, of Landward and Sportscene, visited East Lothian as part of the second series of their TV show lsquoThe Great Food Guysrsquo.The cooking show celebrates Scotlandrsquos food and drink in the pairrsquos Aberdeenshire kitchen, joined by some celebrity guests, inspired by their road trip across Scotland.Dougie said: ldquoWe are back at our countryside kitchen to cook some great food inspired by our road trips.The first show in the eight part series airs tonightat pm on BBC Scotland and will also be shown on Saturdayat .am on BBC One.Tonightrsquos show, recorded before lockdown restrictions began, sees the pair joined by Kaori Simpson, an award-winning chef from Harajuku Kitchen in Edinburgh, and Greg McHugh, an actor of Gary Tank Commander and The A Word fame, who will bring along his choice of craft beer to accompany the food.On the menu is an Asian fusion consisting of salt chilli squid with a Vietnamese dipping sauce, inspired by their trip last April to a farm in East Lothian that grows Asian vegetables, such as pak choi.The name of the farm is not known and was not mentioned when the clips were originally shown on Landward last year.The show also consists of sample sessions filmed last year while out on the road with the Landward van.People in North Berwick enjoyed some food samples around the harbour area last May along with people in Moffat, found in Dumfries and Galloway.Upcoming guests in the show include crime writer Val McDermid, Still Game star Jane McCarry, comedian farmer Jim Smith, TV presenter JJ Chalmers, Call the Midwe star Laura Main, actor and comedian Sanjeev Kohliand weather presenter Judith Ralston.

title: north-berwick-high-school-shares-plan-safe-reopening
